question.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect?

options.text: In monocotyledons, the leaf base expands into a sheath covering the stem partially or wholly.
In some grasses, the leaf base may become swollen, which is called the pulvinus.
The leaf blade is the green expanded part of the leaf with veins and veinlets.
Leaves originate from shoot apical meristems and are arranged in an acropetal order.

solution.text:
The leaf is a lateral, generally flattened structure borne on the stem. It develops at the node and bears a bud in its axil. The axillary bud later develops into a branch. Leaves originate from shoot apical meristems and are arranged in an acropetal order.

In monocotyledons, the leaf base expands into a sheath covering the stem partially or wholly. In some leguminous plants, the leaf base may become swollen, which is called the pulvinus. The lamina or the leaf blade is the green expanded part of the leaf with veins and veinlets. There is, usually, a middle prominent vein, which is known as the midrib. Veins provide rigidity to the leaf blade and act as channels of transport for water, minerals and food materials.
